steps.title: Grate cheese using a microplane cheese grater.
steps.content: Grate cheese using a microplane cheese grater. A microplane cheese grater consists of a handle attached to a long, flat grate with small, sharp teeth. [1] X Research source Although they are usually used for zesting lemons or grating garlic, they are perfectly serviceable when it comes to grating cheese. Because microplanes tend to produce smaller pieces of grated cheese, they are best used with hard cheeses such as Parmesan or Pecorino. Grating a soft cheese like mozzarella with a microplane would only give you a mushy mass instead of cleanly grated cheese.

steps.title: Unwrap your block of cheese.
steps.content: Unwrap your block of cheese. If it is too large to hold comfortably with one hand, slice it into manageable pieces with a knife. Err on the side of larger rather than smaller â€” there's less of a chance you'll hurt yourself with a big piece of cheese.

steps.title: Holding the microplane over a plate or board, gently swipe the cheese against the grate using an up-and-down motion.
steps.content: Holding the microplane over a plate or board, gently swipe the cheese against the grate using an up-and-down motion. Continue until you have the desired amount.

steps.title: Tap the metal end of the grater lightly against the edge of the plate to release excess trimmings.
steps.content: Tap the metal end of the grater lightly against the edge of the plate to release excess trimmings. Use a pastry brush, if necessary, to remove all the cheese trimmings from the microplane.

steps.title: Switch out your microplane size depending on what you're using cheese for.
steps.content: Switch out your microplane size depending on what you're using cheese for. Microplane graters come in a variety of sizes ranging from fine to coarse. [2] X Research source Finely shredded cheese can be used as the top layer of a freshly made pizza. Medium shredded cheese is thicker and a nice topping for baked potatoes or salads. Coarsely grated cheese is the thickest and can be used to garnish pasta.

steps.title: Use a box grater to shred your cheese.
steps.content: Use a box grater to shred your cheese. A box grater is four sided, with each side having differently sized teeth. Because box grates tend to have larger teeth, they work well with softer cheeses such as mozzarella or havarti. Choose whichever grater plate suits the dish. The medium sized holes are great for garnishing tacos, but not so much for making crumb-like Parmesan to go on Spaghetti.

steps.title: Keep your cheese medium to large sized.
steps.content: Keep your cheese medium to large sized. This will prevent you from scraping your fingers before you have the desired amount of shredded cheese.

steps.title: Lightly coat the outside of the grater plate you will be using with cooking spray.
steps.content: Lightly coat the outside of the grater plate you will be using with cooking spray. This will make the cheese glide easier. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Let your box grate decide how you'll use it.
steps.content: Let your box grate decide how you'll use it. For box graters without a handle, hold the cheese and grater over a large bowl. For graters with a handle, place the end of the grater on a cutting board.

steps.title: Rub the cheese against the grater in an up-and-down motion.
steps.content: Rub the cheese against the grater in an up-and-down motion. Once you reach the end of the cheese, rub it with your palm to avoid scraping your knuckles. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Slice your cheese using a rotary grater.
steps.content: Slice your cheese using a rotary grater. A rotary grater consists of a handle connected to a circular grating compartment. A side crank is then rotated to grate the cheese. Raise the top handle of the grater, place a small block of cheese into the compartment, and lower the handle.

steps.title: Apply some pressure to the top of the handle with your thumb.
steps.content: Apply some pressure to the top of the handle with your thumb. Grip the handle normally with your other fingers.

steps.title: Turn the handle with your other hand while aiming the grating compartment at a nearby plate or bowl.
steps.content: Turn the handle with your other hand while aiming the grating compartment at a nearby plate or bowl. Stop whenever you feel like you have enough shredded cheese.

steps.title: Rotary graters are safer as your hands are not required to press against the plates.They are also very efficient and are best reserved for making large quantities of shredded cheese.
steps.content: Rotary graters are safer as your hands are not required to press against the plates.They are also very efficient and are best reserved for making large quantities of shredded cheese. For example, if you need to make nacho dips or breakfast casseroles, use a rotary grater.

steps.title: Shred cheese with a vegetable peeler.
steps.content: Shred cheese with a vegetable peeler. Though not as efficient or glamorous as using a cheese grater, a vegetable peeler will still get the job done. Hold a medium sized block of cheese over a regular sized plate. Rub the peeler against the cheese in a continuous forward motion. For higher quality slices, refrigerate the cheese first or opt for a hard type of cheese (such as Parmesan). [5] X Research source

steps.title: Use a sharp kitchen knife to thinly slice cheese.
steps.content: Use a sharp kitchen knife to thinly slice cheese. Though this is more time consuming, a knife is a nice substitute for a vegetable peeler. Hold a small chunk of cheese against the surface of a plate. Gently slice off thin shreds onto the plate. Opt for a plain edge rather than a serrated edge. Plain edge knives are better at shaving and skinning. [6] X Research source Avoid holding large blocks of cheese. Since knife work is more dangerous than other grating options, you want to have a steady and firm grip on the cheese.

steps.title: Mince cheese with a food processor.
steps.content: Mince cheese with a food processor. For quick and easy shredded cheese, a food processor is the optimal choice. Refrigerate your cheese until it is firm but not too hard. Chop it into smaller blocks and place it in your food processor. [7] X Research source Be cautious about overloading your processor. Some food processor blades have seized up or become unbalanced when grating cheese. [8] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Turn the food processor on and monitor the shape of the cheese shreds. Once you have shredded the cheese to your liking, turn off the processor and empty it onto a plate. If your processor has a shredding disk, select this blade as it will provide better quality slices. Avoid processing softer cheeses such as Mozzarella. This will result in smeared, not shredded, cheese. [9] X Research source
